```{r insert the date and create dataframes, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE}
testing_facet_conf1 <- c(testing_total_new_confirmed_cases_NL, testing_total_new_confirmed_cases_USA, testing_total_new_confirmed_cases_CH, testing_total_new_death_cases_NL, testing_total_new_death_cases_USA, testing_total_new_death_cases_CH)
testing_cum1 <- c(testing_total_confirmed_cases_cum_NL, testing_total_confirmed_cases_cum_USA, testing_total_confirmed_cases_cum_CH, testing_total_death_cases_cum_NL, testing_total_death_cases_cum_USA, testing_total_death_cases_cum_CH)
testing_sort_case <- c(testing_facet_conf, testing_facet_conf, testing_facet_conf, testing_facet_deaths, testing_facet_deaths, testing_facet_deaths)
testing_Country_test <- c(testing_facet_country1, testing_facet_country1)
testing_DB <- data.frame(testing_facet_days, testing_facet_amount_cases, testing_facet_cases, testing_facet_country)
db_test1000 <- data.frame(testing_facet_days, testing_some_days, testing_facet_conf1, testing_cum1, testing_Country_test, testing_sort_case)
```

We are going to create a page with figures that gives us information 'day to day'. 'Day to day' means that we have data about every day, such as the amount of confirmed cases (Corona patients), the USA provides data about the confirmed and the death cases, and The Netherlands provides also data about the hospital cases. Our goal is to compare the two countries, so we are going to use the confirmed case data and the death case data.
We can make a figure with 4 lines, that gives us a quick image that gives us enough information to see the differences when we compare the United states and the American territories with The Netherlands. This figure is presented below; 

We see that in the plot in the upper left corner the line indicates the confirmed cases in The Netherlands, that in the upper right corner the line indicates the death cases in The Netherlands, that in the lower left corner the line indicates the confirmed cases in the United States and the American Territories, and that the line in the lower right corner the line indicates the deaths in the United States and the American territories.
Of course, this figure is not the only figure that we are going to show on this page, but this figure gives us enough information to compare the countries. This is because we can see the dates, and whether a line is stable, increasing or decreasing and the amount of cases (so how much higher the line for the USA is located, compared to the line that represents The Netherlands).
In the figure we see that the big difference between the USA and The Netherlands is that the lines that represent the United States of America and its territories is still not decreasing three months after the first cases. The lines that represent the data for The Netherlands are decreasing, especially the death cases every day. June 23 was the first day with no new Corona deaths, june 22 has 1 death case and since june 12 the corona deaths are under 10 cases per day. We see that the line that indicates the Corona patients per day, is also a decreasing line since begin april. None of the lines are stable, so we can't predict that period with less than 10 Corona deaths per day continuous tomorrow. We see that the big difference is that when the amount of deaths in both countries, which was in begin april, the USA's line did not decrease or increase, but stayed at the same amount of new cases per day. The Netherlands line is a decreasing line sinces its maximum, for both cases (confirmed and death).


Now we are going to make some figures that represent again the information 'day to day' Corona cases. When we look at the figure below we see the new confirmed cases per day. We see that The Netherland's maximum was in april, and that the line is decreasing since the maximum. When we look at the United States and the American territories we see that the maximum was on june 25, so we has not reach the maximum. An important date is the begin of april. The red line indicates the date (april 10 2020) when The Netherlands has a decreasing line and and the USA line is neither decreasing or increasing.

```{r, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE}
testing_DB %>% ggplot(aes(testing_facet_days, testing_facet_amount_cases, group = 1)) + theme_bw() + geom_line(color = "blue") + facet_grid(testing_facet_country ~ testing_facet_cases) + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 60, vjust = 1, hjust = 1)) + scale_y_continuous(trans = "log10") + scale_x_discrete(breaks = testing_some_days_test_db, labels = testing_some_days_test_db) + xlab("Days, notation month-day-year (01 18 2020 is january 18 2020)") + ylab("Amount of cases, log 10 scale") + ggtitle("4 plots that gives information to compare, note that the Y-axis is in log 10") 
```
